title: Mike Stratton
text:
David Michael Stratton (April 10, 1941 – March 25, 2020) was an American professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a> for 12 seasons in the <a href="American%20Football%20League">American Football League</a> (AFL) and <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL). He won two <a href="AFL%20championship">AFL championship</a>s with the <a href="Buffalo%20Bills">Buffalo Bills</a>, where he was a six-time <a href="AFL%20All-Star">AFL All-Star</a>. He was named to the <a href="AFL%20All-Time%20Second%20Team">AFL All-Time Second Team</a>.
Stratton played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the <a href="Tennessee%20Volunteers%20football">Tennessee Volunteers</a>. He played professionally for 11 years with the Bills and spent his final season with the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a>.
Early life.
Stratton attended Tellico Plains High in <a href="Tellico%20Plains%2C%20Tennessee">Tellico Plains, Tennessee</a>, a <a href="hamlet%20%28place%29">hamlet</a> in the <a href="Great%20Smoky%20Mountains">Great Smoky Mountains</a> region. Football players there did not attract <a href="college%20recruiter">college recruiter</a>s, and Tellico Plains athletes rarely went to college. Stratton played <a href="tackle%20%28gridiron%20football%20position%29">tackle</a>, <a href="fullback%20%28gridiron%20football%29">fullback</a> and <a href="wingback%20%28American%20football%29">wingback</a>.
Stratton received a <a href="athletic%20scholarship">scholarship</a> from <a href="Tennessee%20Volunteers%20football">Volunteers</a> coach <a href="Bowden%20Wyatt">Bowden Wyatt</a> to play at the <a href="University%20of%20Tennessee">University of Tennessee</a>. He was a <a href="two-way%20player">two-way player</a> with Tennessee, playing <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a> on offense and <a href="defensive%20end">defensive end</a> on defense.
Professional career.
Drafted out of college by the <a href="Buffalo%20Bills">Buffalo Bills</a> in the 13th round of the <a href="1962%20AFL%20draft">1962 AFL draft</a>, Stratton was selected as an <a href="AFL%20All-Star">AFL All-Star</a> six straight seasons from 1963 through 1968. Bills coach <a href="Lou%20Saban">Lou Saban</a> teamed him with <a href="Harry%20Jacobs%20%28American%20football%29">Harry Jacobs</a> and <a href="John%20Tracey">John Tracey</a> to form one of the best linebacking crews, playing together for 62 consecutive games from 1963 through 1967, a pro football record. They helped the Bills defense hold opposing teams without a 100-yard rusher for seventeen consecutive games in <a href="1964%20AFL%20season">1964</a> and <a href="1965%20AFL%20season">1965</a>, capturing <a href="AFL%20championship">AFL championship</a>s in both years.
In the <a href="1964%20American%20Football%20League%20Championship%20Game">1964 AFL Championship Game</a> against the <a href="San%20Diego%20Chargers">San Diego Chargers</a>, Stratton made the memorable "hit heard 'round the world". San Diego's <a href="Keith%20Lincoln">Keith Lincoln</a> had a 38-yard run on the game's opening play. The Chargers were leading 7–0 when Stratton drove his shoulder into Lincoln's midsection, breaking the star <a href="running%20back">running back</a>'s ribs and knocking him out of the game. The Bills shut out San Diego for the rest of the game, and won 20–7. In the closing minutes of the first half with Buffalo leading 13–7, the Chargers drove to the Bills' 15, but Stratton <a href="intercepted">intercepted</a> a <a href="Tobin%20Rote">Tobin Rote</a> pass to end the threat. Rote and San Diego coach <a href="Sid%20Gillman">Sid Gillman</a> called the turnover a decisive play.
Stratton played 11 seasons for the Bills before ending his career with the Chargers in 1973. He finished his career with 21 interceptions—18 with the Bills and 3 with the Chargers. He was selected to the <a href="American%20Football%20League%20All-Time%20Team">AFL All-Time Second Team</a>.
Later years.
After football, Stratton became an executive with insurance company Crump Associates in <a href="Knoxville%2C%20Tennessee">Knoxville, Tennessee</a>.
On March 25, 2020, Stratton died at age 78 from heart complications after a recent fall.
